description: Just can't get it removed from my app store

Replaced aText which I use on macos and Breevy which I use on windows. It is a better option than both for my case because it is faster and have several trigger options, it can correct my typos, expand keywords into programming code, has built in scripts with examples. Excellent software and interface.
Super useful and saves a ton of time when you find yourself using the same snippets time and time again.

Was getting nothing when the hotkeys and abbreviations were triggered so I started googleing. It turns out that this version is about 7 years old and not supported any more. soruce: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/autokey-users/Y2fcgYuWP9A

This software allows you to type short phrases which is then replaced by longer text that you use. It also has other useful features and supports python scripting so it's easy to hack. I hear this is what PhraseExpress for Windows is like, but I've never used it.
cool, closest you can get to autohotkey from windows in linux

The only app I found where it worked was text editor app included in ubuntu 18. My word processor, my email doesn't works with it. Also, it can't handle foreign characters such as the Thai Baht Symbol, the hacek diacritic in Slovenian. All it inserts is a blank space instead of the text. I continue my hunt for a text substitution utility. This one was a waste of time.

I was looking for an application just like MACOS text replacement for Linux, couldn't find it. Only found this one. This app completely solved my problem. Abbreviations are kind of buggy but shortcuts work perfectly fine. Highly recommend, this time saving app.
summary: Great app, just what I wanted

description: It looks awesome and if it worked the way the docs suggest, it would def be a 5 star product, but doesn't work in Ubuntu 19.04

The last update is almost a decade old but coded so that it is still relevant. There are some conventions that it does not follow. The triggers fire better than 9/10 times. All of the trigger characters are removed over 7/10 of the time. It does not work in vi or vim.

Crashes a lot,
send out "keyboard.send_keys("")" instead the text in it lol
can't work on ubuntu without it.
This app saves me a great deal of time by providing shortcuts for long and repetitive terms and phrases.
Simple to use, works well on Ubuntu 20.04
summary: Ideal for reoccuring copy & paste tasks

description: agree with Tom, uninstalling now

Not sure what the one star reviews are talking about, but it works perfectly for me in Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS. I'm basically only using phrases (haven't tried scripts) and I've noticed that they work best pasted using "Clipboard (Ctrl+V)" rather than the default "Keyboard."

GTK version, when trying to set up a shortcut via SET button I can click the "helper" key, but when I press the Button to select the letter key it says press key, of course I press a key, but nothing happens, can't set up the shortcut...not sure what's wrong here, but doesn't work for me

Finally found something simple and working.
And it runs on shortcuts!

I used an ancient MS Windows program called Shortkeys for many years, and spend a lot of time looking for a similar program for text macros on Linux before settling on this one. I don't use any of the features other than using keystrokes to paste canned text in anywhere. This capability vastly increases my productivity. If anyone knows of a better, or even a passable alternative, I'd be glad to know about it, since AutoKey may not be available forever or for all systems.
summary: Not Perfect, Only the Best of its Kind that I've Found

description: Tried on two systems, 4 different instal methods, none capture keys.
In ubuntu 21.10 I can't set hotkeys and if i use config files fron the qt version it shows the hotkeys but they still doesn't work. But on another computer running Pop!Os 21.04 it works fine.

It helped alot and did what it supposed to i needed it soo badly THANK GOD
Hat geholfen und mein Leben gerettet.
summary: It helped so much i needed it
